awd_titl_txt: Thermal Evaporation around Optically-Excited Functionalized Nanoparticles
awd_abstract_narration:
Optical absorber-assisted thermal evaporation can enable a variety of innovative renewable energy applications, ranging from water purification to chemical fractionation. Many of these applications can catalyze new industries and hence drive global economic growth. For example, the ability to use solar energy for fresh water production will tackle many challenges in the water-energy nexus. The present project is motivated by a recently observed liquid evaporation using highly localized heating effect from functionalized light absorbing nanoparticles. In such a demonstration, water vapor was generated while the bulk temperature remained at about 30 degrees C. The underlying physics is not yet understood, and the mechanism is related to the convoluted multi-phase (liquid-vapor-solid) thermal and mass transport, which needs this multi-disciplinary study to unlock. The fundamental thermal transport science to be gained from this project is expected to guide the development of new technologies to utilize solar energy, resulting in significant broader impacts on applications. This project will enable the education and training of graduate students and undergraduate students from under-represented groups in the universities.

This project is driven by the hypothesis that enhanced interfacial thermal transport and the self-assembled monolayer defect-assisted nucleation combine to enhance bubble generation and improve the overall evaporation effect. To test this hypothesis, the objectives of this proposal are to (1) understand the fundamental relationship between the surface functionalization, thermal transport and the subsequently mass transport in bubble dynamics through a combination of molecular simulations and mesoscale hydrodynamics modeling; and (2) validate such a relationship through experiments on vapor generation around photo-excited functionalized nanoparticles. This project will employ a combination of molecular simulation, mesoscale modeling and experimental validation to achieve a multi-scale understanding of this fundamental problem with unprecedented resolution.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: Light-enabled thermal evaporation can enable a variety of innovative renewable energy applications, ranging from water purification to chemical fractionation. Many of these applications can catalyze new industries and hence drive global economic growth. For example, the ability to use solar energy for fresh water production will tackle many challenges in the water-energy nexus. Using solar energy for chemical fractionation, which is essential to the energy production industry (e.g., petroleum refining and biofuel purification), may bring revolutionary impact on a sustainable future of the global energy production landscape. 

This proposal was motivated by the PI?s recently demonstrated liquid evaporation using highly localized heating effects from specially functionalized light absorbing nanoparticles (NPs). In such a demonstration, water vapor was generated while the bulk temperature remained at ~30 oC. While this preliminary result highlighted the importance of surface functionalization for evaporation, the underlying physics was not yet understood and is essential for the further advancement of this technology for specific applications. The mechanism behind such processes was related to the convoluted multi-phase (liquid-vapor-solid) thermal and mass transport, which needs a multi-disciplinary study to unlock. This project was driven by the hypothesis that enhanced interfacial thermal transport and the self-assembled monolayer defect-assisted nucleation combine to enhance nanobubble generation and improve the overall evaporation effect. To test this hypothesis, the objectives of this proposal were to (1) understand the fundamental relationship between the surface functionalization, thermal transport and the subsequently mass transport in bubble dynamics through a combination of molecular simulations and mesoscale hydrodynamics modeling; and (2) validate such a relationship through experiments on vapor generation around photo-excited functionalized NPs. 

Intellectual Merit: This inter-disciplinary proposal combined the strong and complementary expertise from three investigators: Tengfei Luo (molecular-level transport, thermal science and engineering; University of Notre Dame (UND)), Hsueh-Chia Chang (fluid dynamics, cavitation dynamics; UND), and Annette Raigoza (surface chemistry, materials synthesis; College of Saint Benedict and Saint John?s University (CSB|SJU)). The proposed project has strong scientific importance and practical implications. Understanding the underlying thermal transport physics involved in the light-induced localized evaporation around plasmonic nanoparticles is critical to the rational design of light absorbers to further develop potential applications such as localized hyperthermia cancer therapy. The combination of molecular simulation, mesoscale modeling and experimental validation led to a multi-scale understanding of this fundamental problem with unprecedented resolution. 

Broader Impact: The fundamental thermal transport science gained from this project was able to guide the development of new technologies to utilize light-enabled local nanobubble formation for a broad range of applications. For example, we have observed that surface bubble formation can be achieved on an optically transparent substrate when immersed in a plasmonic nanoparticle suspension. Such bubbles could also be directed to move by a laser. Such a surface bubble was able to generate a special flow field to collect analytes in the liquid for better sensing. In addition, the ability to use solar energy for water treatment will be especially beneficial for low-resource settings such as underdeveloped regions, disaster relief, extended space flights and military expeditions, where accessing fresh water is either economically or physically difficult. Besides advancing knowledge and technology, the proposed research will also enable the education and training of a large number of graduate students and undergraduate students from under-represented groups at ND and CSB|SJU. 

Outcome of the research: This project successfully provided the understanding of thermal and mass transport near functionalized nanoparticle surfaces when subject to light excitation. This multiphase and multi-scale phenomena open up a new field for nanoscale thermofluids. The research team observed interesting nanoparticle movements with unprecedented speed in fluids, which are potentially useful for nanoswimmer applications. The light-driven nanoparticles can be deposited at surfaces and function as seeds for surface bubble nucleation. The surface bubble can be directed by laser heating for pattern writing. The supercavitation also helps achieve the liquid-nanoparticle separation, allowing driving the nanoparticles out of the liquid without being stranded by the capillary force. This can potentially lead to deposition of nanoparticles without exposing the substrate in liquid, which can be important for some applications like microelectronics. Surface functionalization of plasmonic nanoparticles is shown to change the nanobubble nucleation threshold by as much as one order of magnitude, which can potentially enable laser-enabled targeted cancer therapy with ultra-low light fluence to increase efficacy while minimizing side effects. This project has led to 16 journal papers, one provisional patent application, five invited talks, and seven contributed conference presentations. Two papers were highlighted as journal covers.
